An anatomical description of, or treatise on, the skin.
One who discourses on the skin and its diseases; one versed in dermatology.
The science which treats of the skin, its structure, functions, and diseases.
Of or pertaining to skin diseases, or their cure.
A vegetable parasite, infesting the skin.

A genus of coleopterous insects, the larv\'91 of which feed animal substances. They are very destructive to dries meats, skins, woolens, and furs. The most common species is D. lardarius, known as the bacon beetle.
Pertaining to or resembling the genus Dermestes.
Relating to the derm or skin.
A group of nudibranch mollusks without special gills.
Having the skin modified to serve as a gill.
Pertaining to, or in relation with, both dermal and h\'91mal structures; as, the dermoh\'91mal spines or ventral fin rays of fishes.
The division of insects which includes the earwigs (Forticulid\'91).
A group of fishlike animals including the Marsipobranchiata and Leptocardia.
Ossification of the dermis.
A gatepost or doorpost.
To annul in part; to repeal partly; to restrict; to limit the action of; -- said of a law.
To take away; to detract; to withdraw; -- usually with from.
The act of derogating, partly repealing, or lessening in value; disparagement; detraction; depreciation; -- followed by of, from, or to.
In a derogatory manner; disparagingly.
Tending to derogate, or lessen in value; expressing derogation; detracting; injurious; -- with from to, or unto.
A Turkish or Persian monk, especially one who professes extreme poverty and leads an austere life.
Originally, a double song; a melody or counterpoint sung above the plain song of the tenor; a variation of an air; a variation by ornament of the main subject or plain song.
To sing a variation or accomplishment.
To pass from a higher to a lower place; to move downwards; to come or go down in any way, as by falling, flowing, walking, etc.; to plunge; to fall; to incline downward; -- the opposite of ascend.
One who descends, as offspring, however remotely; -- correlative to ancestor or ascendant.
The quality of being descendible; capability of being transmitted from ancestors; as, the descendibility of an estate.
Admitting descent; capable of being descended.
The act of going downward; descent; falling or sinking; declension; degradation.
The act of descending, or passing downward; change of place from higher to lower.
To represent by drawing; to draw a plan of; to delineate; to trace or mark out; as, to describe a circle by the compasses; a torch waved about the head in such a way as to describe a circle.
The act of describing; a delineation by marks or signs.
To spy out or discover by the eye, as objects distant or obscure; to espy; to recognize; to discern; to discover.
To divest of a sacred character or office; to divert from a sacred purpose; to violate the sanctity of; to profane; to put to an unworthy use; -- the opposite of consecrate.
That which is deserved; the reward or the punishment justly due; claim to recompense, usually in a good sense; right to reward; merit.
A deserted or forsaken region; a barren tract incapable of supporting population, as the vast sand plains of Asia and Africa are destitute and vegetation.

To leave (especially something which one should stay by and support); to leave in the lurch; to abandon; to forsake; -- implying blame, except sometimes when used of localities; as, to desert a friend, a principle, a cause, one's country.

The act of deserting or forsaking; abandonment of a service, a cause, a party, a friend, or any post of duty; the quitting of one's duties willfully and without right; esp., an absconding from military or naval service.
To earn by service; to be worthy of (something due, either good or evil); to merit; to be entitled to; as, the laborer deserves his wages; a work of value deserves praise.
An undress; a careless toilet.
The act of desiccating, or the state of being desiccated.
Drying; tending to dry.
One who, or that which, desiccates.
To desire; to feel the want of; to lack; to miss; to want.
An object of desire.
The state or quality of being desidiose, or indolent.
The act of making unsightly; disfigurement.
To draw preliminary outline or main features of; to sketch for a pattern or model; to delineate; to trace out; to draw.
A preliminary sketch; an outline or pattern of the main features of something to be executed, as of a picture, a building, or a decoration; a delineation; a plan.

To mark out and make known; to point out; to name; to indicate; to show; to distinguish by marks or description; to specify; as, to designate the boundaries of a country; to designate the rioters who are to be arrested.
The act of designating; a pointing out or showing; indication.
An officer who assigned to each his rank and place in public shows and ceremonies.
By design; purposely; intentionally; -- opposed to accidentally, ignorantly, or inadvertently.
One who designs, marks out, or plans; a contriver.
The act of making designs or sketches; the act of forming designs or plans.
Delineation; sketch; design; ideal; invention.
The act or the process of freeing from silver; also, the condition resulting from the removal of silver.
To deprive, or free from, silver; to remove silver from.
The state or quality of being desirable; desirableness.
Worthy of desire or longing; fitted to excite desire or a wish to possess; pleasing; agreeable.
To long for; to wish for earnestly; to covet.
The natural longing that is excited by the enjoyment or the thought of any good, and impels to action or effort its continuance or possession; an eager wish to obtain or enjoy.
Feeling desire; eagerly wishing; solicitous; eager to obtain; covetous.
The state of being desirous.
To cease to proceed or act; to stop; to forbear; -- often with from.
An end or ending.
Final; serving to complete; conclusive.
A table, frame, or case, usually with sloping top, but often with flat top, for the use writers and readers. It often has a drawer or repository underneath.
Work done at a desk, as by a clerk or writer.
A microscopic plant of the family Desmidi\'91, a group of unicellular alg\'91 in which the species have a greenish color, and the cells generally appear as if they consisted of two coalescing halves.
Same as Stilbite. It commonly occurs in bundles or tufts of crystals.
A member of a group of South American blood-sucking bats, of the genera Desmodus and Diphylla. See Vampire.

Having the maxillo-palatine bones united; -- applied to a group of carinate birds (Desmognath\'91), including various wading and swimming birds, as the ducks and herons, and also raptorial and other kinds.
Resembling, or having the characteristics of, a ligament; ligamentous.
The science which treats of the ligaments.
The division of Tunicata which includes the Salp\'91. See Salpa.
Destitute or deprived of inhabitants; deserted; uninhabited; hence, gloomy; as, a desolate isle; a desolate wilderness; a desolate house.
To make desolate; to leave alone; to deprive of inhabitants; as, the earth was nearly desolated by the flood.
The state of being desolate.
One who, or that which, desolates or lays waste.
The act of desolating or laying waste; destruction of inhabitants; depopulation.
To be hopeless; to have no hope; to give up all hope or expectation; -- often with of.
To give up as beyond hope or expectation; to despair of.
Loss of hope; utter hopelessness; complete despondency.
To scatter; to disparkle.
To discriminate; to separate according to specific signification or qualities; to specificate; to desynonymize.
Without hope; given to despair; hopeless.
In a desperate manner; without regard to danger or safety; recklessly; extremely; as, the troops fought desperately.
The act of despairing or becoming desperate; a giving up of hope.
In a despicable or mean manner; contemptibly; as, despicably stingy.
A looking down; despection.
Malice; malignity; spite; malicious anger; contemptuous hate.
Despiteous; very angry; cruel.
To strip, as of clothing; to divest or unclothe.
A stripping or plundering; spoliation.
In a desponding manner.
A master; a lord; especially, an absolute or irresponsible ruler or sovereign.
The power, spirit, or principles of a despot; absolute control over others; tyrannical sway; tyranny.
To act the despot.
To throw off impurities in spume; to work off in foam or scum; to foam.
The act of throwing up froth or scum; separation of the scum or impurities from liquids; scumming; clarification.
To free from spume or scum.
The separation or shedding of the cuticle or epidermis in the form of flakes or scales; exfoliation, as of bones.
Of, pertaining to, or attended with, desquamation.
An instrument formerly used in removing the lamin\'91 of exfoliated bones.
A service of pastry, fruits, or sweetmeats, at the close of a feast or entertainment; pastry, fruits, etc., forming the last course at dinner.
Determined by destiny; fated.

That to which any person or thing is destined; predetermined state; condition foreordained by the Divine or by human will; fate; lot; doom.
Forsaken; not having in possession (something necessary, or desirable); deficient; lacking; devoid; -- often followed by of.

Liable to destruction; capable of being destroyed.
The quality of being destructible.
The act of destroying; a tearing down; a bringing to naught; subversion; demolition; ruin; slaying; devastation.

In a destructive manner.
The quality of destroying or ruining.
Disused; out of use.
The cessation of use; disuse; discontinuance of practice, custom, or fashion.
The act or process of depriving of sulphur.
To desulphurate; to deprive of sulphur.
In a desultory manner; without method; loosely; immethodically.

Leaping or skipping about.
To deprive of synonymous character; to discriminate in use; -- applied to words which have been employed as synonyms.
To part; to separate or disunite; to disengage; -- the opposite of attach; as, to detach the coats of a bulbous root from each other; to detach a man from a leader or from a party.
Separate; unconnected, or imperfectly connected; as, detached parcels.
The act of detaching or separating, or the state of being detached.
A minute portion; one of the small parts; a particular; an item; -- used chiefly in the plural; as, the details of a scheme or transaction.
To relate in particulars; to particularize; to report minutely and distinctly; to enumerate; to specify; as, he detailed all the facts in due order.
To keep back or from; to withhold.
To uncover; to discover; to find out; to bring to light; as, to detect a crime or a criminal; to detect a mistake in an account.
The act of detecting; the laying open what was concealed or hidden; discovery; as, the detection of a thief; the detection of fraud, forgery, or a plot.
One who business it is so detect criminals or discover matters of secrecy.
One who, or that which, detects; a detecter.
The act of detaining or keeping back; a withholding.
A cleansing quality or power.
To make worse; to make inferior in quality or value; to impair; as, to deteriorate the mind.
Worse state or quality; inferiority.
Serving to determine or limit; determinative.
That which serves to determine; that which causes determination.
Having defined limits; not uncertain or arbitrary; fixed; established; definite.
In a determinate manner; definitely; ascertainably.
The act of determining, or the state of being determined.
To fix the boundaries of; to mark off and separate.
To come to an end; to end; to terminate.
One who, or that which, determines or decides.
The doctrine that the will is not free, but is inevitably and invincibly determined by motives.
The uncovering of anything buried or covered with earth; a taking out of the earth or ground.
The act of deterging or cleansing, as a sore.
In a way to cleanse.
The quality of cleansing.
To witness against; to denounce; to condemn.
In a detestable manner.
To remove or drive from a throne; to depose; to divest of supreme authority and dignity.
To cause to explode; to cause to burn or inflame with a sudden report.
One who, or that which, detonates.
The act of detonizing; detonation.
To explode, or cause to explode; to burn with an explosion; to detonate.
To turn form the original or plain meaning; to pervert; to wrest.
A turning; a circuitous route; a deviation from a direct course; as, the detours of the Mississippi.
To take away; to withdraw.
A taking away or withdrawing.
Tending to detractor draw.
One who detracts; a derogator; a defamer.
That which injures or causes damage; mischief; harm; diminution; loss; damage; -- used very generically; as, detriments to property, religion, morals, etc.
Pertaining to, or composed of, detritus.
A wearing off or away.
A mass of substances worn off from solid bodies by attrition, and reduced to small portions; as, diluvial detritus.
The act of lopping or cutting off, as the head from the body.
The act of thrusting or driving down or outward; outward thrust.
Two; a card or a die with two spots; as, the deuce of hearts.
Pertaining to a second canon, or ecclesiastical writing of inferior authority; -- said of the Apocrypha, certain Epistles, etc.
One who marries the second time.
A second marriage, after the death of the first husband of wife; -- in distinction from bigamy, as defined in the old canon law. See Bigamy.
The writer of Deuteronomy.
The fifth book of the Pentateuch, containing the second giving of the law by Moses.
A sympathetic affection of any part of the body, as headache from an overloaded stomach.
Pertaining to deuteropathy; of the nature of deuteropathy.

A prefix which formerly properly indicated the second in a regular series of compound in the series, and not to its composition, but which is now generally employed in the same sense as bi- or di-, although little used.
A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of hydrogen united with some other element or radical.
The lifeless food matter in the cytoplasm of an ovum or a cell, as distinguished from the active or true protoplasm; yolk substance; yolk.
Pertaining to, or composed of, deutoplasm.
A compound containing in the molecule two atoms of oxygen united with some other element or radical; -- usually called dioxide, or less frequently, binoxide.
A genus of shrubs with pretty white flowers, much cultivated.
A god; a deity; a divine being; an idol; a king.
The character in which Sanskrit is written.
The change of vapor into water, as in the formation of rain.
The act of devastating, or the state of being devastated; a laying waste.

To free from that which infolds or envelops; to unfold; to lay open by degrees or in detail; to make visible or known; to disclose; to produce or give forth; as, to develop theories; a motor that develops 100 horse power.

To go through a process of natural evolution or growth, by successive changes from a less perfect to a more perfect or more highly organized state; to advance from a simpler form of existence to one more complex either in structure or function; as, a blossom develops from a bud; the seed develops into a plant; the embryo develops into a well-formed animal; the mind develops year by year.
One who, or that which, develops.

The act of developing or disclosing that which is unknown; a gradual unfolding process by which anything is developed, as a plan or method, or an image upon a photographic plate; gradual advancement or growth through a series of progressive changes; also, the result of developing, or a developed state.
To divest; to undress.
To go out of the way; to turn aside from a course or a method; to stray or go astray; to err; to digress; to diverge; to vary.
The act of deviating; a wandering from the way; variation from the common way, from an established rule, etc.; departure, as from the right course or the path of duty.
Tending to deviate; devious; as, deviatory motion.
That which is devised, or formed by design; a contrivance; an invention; a project; a scheme; often, a scheme to deceive; a stratagem; an artifice.
The Evil One; Satan, represented as the tempter and spiritual of mankind.
To make like a devil; to invest with the character of a devil.
Resembling, characteristic of, or pertaining to, the devil; diabolical; wicked in the extreme.
Conduct suitable to the devil; extreme wickedness; deviltry.
The character or person of a devil or the devil.
Out of a straight line; winding; varying from directness; as, a devious path or way.
To deprive of virginity; to deflour.
Capable of being devised, invented, or contrived.

To form in the mind by new combinations of ideas, new applications of principles, or new arrangement of parts; to formulate by thought; to contrive; to excogitate; to invent; to plan; to scheme; as, to devise an engine, a new mode of writing, a plan of defense, or an argument.
The act of giving or disposing of real estate by will; -- sometimes improperly applied to a bequest of personal estate.
One to whom a devise is made, or real estate given by will.
One who devises, or gives real estate by will; a testator; -- correlative to devisee.
To deprive of life or vitality.
An avoiding or escaping; also, a warning.
To deprive of glasslike character; to take away vitreous luster and transparency from.
To make toneless; to deprive of vowel quality.
The act of rolling down.
To roll onward or downward; to pass on.

One of a breed of hardy cattle originating in the country of Devon, England. Those of pure blood have a deep red color. The small, longhorned variety, called North Devons, is distinguished by the superiority of its working oxen.
Of or pertaining to Devon or Devonshire in England; as, the Devonian rocks, period, or system.
The act of devouring.
To appropriate by vow; to set apart or dedicate by a solemn act; to consecrate; also, to consign over; to doom; to evil; to devote one to destruction; the city was devoted to the flames.
One who is wholly devoted; esp., one given wholly to religion; one who is superstitiously given to religious duties and ceremonies; a bigot.
The act of devoting; consecration.
One given to devotion, esp. to excessive formal devotion.
The practice of a devotionalist.
To eat up with greediness; to consume ravenously; to feast upon like a wild beast or a glutton; to prey upon.
One who, or that which, devours.
In a devouring manner.
Devoted to religion or to religious feelings and duties; absorbed in religious exercises; given to devotion; pious; reverent; religious.
In a devout and reverent manner; with devout emotions; piously.
To give up; to devote.
Moisture from the atmosphere condensed by cool bodies upon their surfaces, particularly at night.
State of being dewy.
The pendulous skin under the neck of an ox, which laps or licks the dew in grazing.
To ret or rot by the process called dewretting.
Dewrotting; the process of decomposing the gummy matter of flax and hemp and setting the fibrous part, by exposure on a sward to dew, rain, and sunshine.
To rot, as flax or hemp, by exposure to rain, dew, and sun. See Dewretting.
Pertaining to dew; resembling, consisting of, or moist with, dew.
Pertaining to, or situated on, the right hand; right, as opposed to sinister, or left.
Ready and expert in the use of the body and limbs; skillful and active with the hands; handy; ready; as, a dexterous hand; a dexterous workman.
The quality of being dexterous; dexterity.
Toward the right side; dextrally.
Right, as opposed to sinistral, or left.
A war horse; a destrer.
A prefix, from L. dexter, meaning, pertaining to, or toward, the right
Pertaining to, or derived from, dextrose; as, dextronic acid.
Turning, or causing to turn, toward the right hand; esp., turning the plane of polarization of luminous rays toward the right hand; as, dextrorotatory crystals, sugars, etc.  Cf. Levorotatory.
Turning from the left to the right, in the ascending line, as in the spiral inclination of the stem of the common morning-gl\'a2ry.
A servant who has charge of the dairy; a dairymaid.
To deprive of, or free from, zinc.
A fierce, wild dog (Canis Dukhunensis), found in the mountains of India. It is remarkable for its propensity to hunt the tiger and other wild animals in packs.
A Ceylonese boat. See Doni.
A coasting vessel of Arabia, East Africa, and the Indian Ocean. It has generally but one mast and a lateen sail.
A prefix, signifying twofold, double, twice
A prefix denoting through; also, between, apart, asunder, across. Before a vowel dia- becomes di-; as, diactinic; dielectric, etc.

A basic, dark-colored, holocrystalline, igneous rock, consisting essentially of a triclinic feldspar and pyroxene with magnetic iron; -- often limited to rocks pretertiary in age. It includes part of what was early called greenstone.
Passing over the borders.
Pertaining to the devil; resembling, or appropriate, or appropriate to, the devil; devilish; infernal; impious; atrocious; nefarious; outrageously wicked; as, a diabolic or diabolical temper or act.
To ascribed diabolical qualities to; to change into, or to represent as, a devil.
Character, action, or principles appropriate to the devil.
A universal remedy; -- name formerly to a purgative electuary.
Pertaining to, or possessing the properties of, a species of caustic curves formed by refraction. See Caustic surface, under Caustic.
That which burns by refraction, as a double convex lens, or the sun's rays concentrated by such a lens, sometimes used as a cautery.
Divalent; -- said of a base or radical as capable of saturating two acid monad radicals or a dibasic acid. Cf. Dibasic, a., and Biacid.
A sirup made of poppies.
Of or pertaining to a deacon.
The office of a deacon; deaconship; also, a body or board of deacons.
Pertaining to the science or doctrine of refracted sounds.
That branch of natural philosophy which treats of the properties of sound as affected by passing through different mediums; -- called also diaphonics. See the Note under Acoustics.
That separates or distinguishes; -- applied to points or marks used to distinguish letters of similar form, or different sounds of the same letter, as, \'be, &acr;, \'84, &omac;, &ocr;, etc.
A Linn\'91an class of plants whose stamens are united into two bodies or bundles by their filaments.

Of or pertaining to the class Diadelphia; having the stamens united into two bodies by their filaments (said of a plant or flower); grouped into two bundles or sets by coalescence of the filaments (said of stamens).
Originally, an ornamental head band or fillet, worn by Eastern monarchs as a badge of royalty; hence (later), also, a crown, in general.
The separation or resolution of one syllable into two; -- the opposite of syn\'91resis.
Relating to, or exhibiting, diageotropism.
The tendency of organs (as roots) of plants to assume a position oblique or transverse to a direction towards the center of the earth.
To ascertain by diagnosis; to diagnosticate. See Diagnosticate.
The art or act of recognizing the presence of disease from its signs or symptoms, and deciding as to its character; also, the decision arrived at.
The mark or symptom by which one disease is known or distinguished from others.
To make a diagnosis of; to recognize by its symptoms, as a disease.
That part of medicine which has to do with ascertaining the nature of diseases by means of their symptoms or signs.
A right line drawn from one angle to another not adjacent, of a figure of four or more sides, and dividing it into two parts.
Diagonal; diametrical; hence; diametrically opposed.
A figure or drawing made to illustrate a statement, or facilitate a demonstration; a plan.
Pertaining to, or of the nature of, a diagram; showing by diagram.
A drawing instrument, combining a protractor and scale.
The art or science of descriptive drawing; especially, the art or science of drawing by mechanical appliances and mathematical rule.
Relating or, or manifesting, diaheliotropism.
A tendency of leaves or other organs of plants to have their dorsal surface faced towards the rays of light.

An instrument, formerly much used for showing the time of day from the shadow of a style or gnomon on a graduated arc or surface; esp., a sundial; but there are lunar and astral dials. The style or gnomon is usually parallel to the earth's axis, but the dial plate may be either horizontal or vertical.
To measure with a dial.
Means or mode of expressing thoughts; language; tongue; form of speech.
Pertaining to dialectics; logical; argumental.
One versed in dialectics; a logician; a reasoner.

That branch of logic which teaches the rules and modes of reasoning; the application of logical principles to discursive reasoning; the science or art of discriminating truth from error; logical discussion.
The art of constructing dials; the science which treats of measuring time by dials.
A figure by which arguments are placed in various points of view, and then turned to one point.
Meeting and intersecting, as lines; not parallel; -- opposed to parallel.
Relating to a dialogue; dialogistical.
A speaker in a dialogue.
Native carbonate of manganese; rhodochrosite.
To discourse in dialogue.
A conversation between two or more persons; particularly, a formal conservation in theatrical performances or in scholastic exercises.
Di\'91resis. See Di\'91resis, 1.
The act or process of dialysis.
To separate, prepare, or obtain, by dialysis or osmose; to pass through an animal membrane; to subject to dialysis.
Prepared by diffusion through an animal membrane; as, dialyzed iron.
The instrument or medium used to effect chemical dialysis.
A body having diamagnetic polarity.
Pertaining to, or exhibiting the phenomena of, diamagnetism; taking, or being of a nature to take, a position at right angles to the lines of magnetic force. See Paramagnetic.
In the manner of, or according to, diamagnetism.
The science which treats of diamagnetic phenomena, and of the properties of diamagnetic bodies.

Any right line passing through the center of a figure or body, as a circle, conic section, sphere, cube, etc., and terminated by the opposite boundaries; a straight line which bisects a system of parallel chords drawn in a curve.
Of or pertaining to a diameter.
A prefix or combining form of Diamine. [Also used adjectively.]
A compound containing two amido groups united with one or more basic or positive radicals, -- as contrasted with a diamide.
A precious stone or gem excelling in brilliancy and beautiful play of prismatic colors, and remarkable for extreme hardness.
The salt-marsh terrapin of the Atlantic coast (Malacoclemmys palustris).
Having figures like a diamond or lozenge.
A liquid hydrocarbon, C10H20, of the ethylene series, regarded as a polymeric form of amylene.
The daughter of Jupiter and Latona; a virgin goddess who presided over hunting, chastity, and marriage; -- identified with the Greek goddess Artemis.
Of or pertaining to the class Diandria; having two stamens.
Pertaining to the discursive faculty, its acts or products.
The octave, or interval which includes all the tones of the diatonic scale.
The interval of the fifth.
Any textile fabric (esp. linen or cotton toweling) woven in diaper pattern. See 2.
To ornament with figures, etc., arranged in the pattern called diaper, as cloth in weaving.
A woven silk stuff with transparent and colored figures; diaper work.
The quality of being diaphanous; transparency; pellucidness.
Having power to transmit light; transparent; diaphanous.
The art of imitating <?/<?/ined glass with translucent paper.
An instrument for measuring the transparency of the air.
A dark box constructed for viewing transparent pictures, with or without a lens.
A colored photograph produced by superimposing a translucent colored positive over a strong uncolored one.
Allowing light to pass through, as porcelain; translucent or transparent; pellucid; clear.
Relating to the measurement of the tactile sensibility of parts; as, diaphemetric compasses.
The doctrine of refracted sound; diacoustics.
Perspiration, or an increase of perspiration.
Having the power to increase perspiration.
A medicine or agent which promotes perspiration.
A dividing membrane or thin partition, commonly with an opening through it.
An abnormal prolongation of the axis of inflorescence.
Pertaining to a diapophysis.
The dorsal transverse, or tubercular, process of a vertebra. See Vertebra.
A form of government in which the supreme power is vested in two persons.
Pertaining to a diary; daily.
One who keeps a diary.
A morbidly frequent and profuse discharge of loose or fluid evacuations from the intestines, without tenesmus; a purging or looseness of the bowels; a flux.
Of or pertaining to diarrhea; like diarrhea.
Producing diarrhea, or a purging.
Relating to diarthrosis, or movable articulations.
A form of articulation which admits of considerable motion; a complete joint; abarticulation. See Articulation.
A register of daily events or transactions; a daily record; a journal; a blank book dated for the record of daily memoranda; as, a diary of the weather; a physician's diary.
lasting for one day; as, a diary
A soluble, nitrogenous ferment, capable of converting starch and dextrin into sugar.
A forcible of bones without fracture.
Relating to diastase; having the properties of diastase; effecting the conversion of starch into sugar.
A vacant space, or gap, esp. between teeth in a jaw.

A double star; -- applied to the nucleus of a cell, when, during cell division, the loops of the nuclear network separate into two groups, preparatory to the formation of two daughter nuclei. See Karyokinesis.
The rhythmical expansion or dilatation of the heart and arteries; -- correlative to systole, or contraction.
The interval of a fourth.
The property of transmitting radiant heat; the quality of being diathermous.
Affording a free passage to heat; as, diathermic substances.
Bodily condition or constitution, esp. a morbid habit which predisposes to a particular disease, or class of diseases.
Pertaining to, or dependent on, a diathesis or special constitution of the body; as, diathetic disease.

One of the Diatomace\'91, a family of minute unicellular Alg\'91 having a siliceous covering of great delicacy, each individual multiplying by spontaneous division. By some authors diatoms are called Bacillari\'91, but this word is not in general use.
Having a single, distinct, diagonal cleavage; -- said of crystals.
A prolonged or exhaustive discussion; especially, an acrimonious or invective harangue; a strain of abusive or railing language; a philippic.
An extinct eocene bird from New Mexico, larger than the ostrich.
Disjoining two fourths; as, the diazeutic tone, which, like that from F to G in modern music, lay between two fourths, and, being joined to either, made a fifth.

A combining form  (also used adjectively), meaning pertaining to, or derived from, a series of compounds containing a radical of two nitrogen atoms, united usually to an aromatic radical; as, diazo-benzene, C6H5.N2.OH.
One of the small bones in the knee joints of sheep uniting the bones above and below the joints.
To dib or dip frequently, as in angling.
To plant with a dibble; to make holes in (soil) with a dibble, for planting.

An order of cephalopods which includes those with two gills, an apparatus for emitting an inky fluid, and either eight or ten cephalic arms bearing suckers or hooks, as the octopi and squids. See Cephalopoda.
Having two atoms or equivalents of calcium to the molecule.
Containing two carbon residues, or two carboxyl or radicals; as, oxalic acid is a dicarbonic acid.
A functionary in ancient Athens answering nearly to the modern juryman.
A court of justice; judgment hall.
To play games with dice.
Having two heads on one body; double-headed.
A player at dice; a dice player; a gamester.
Capable of subdividing spontaneously.
Having two coverings, a calyx and in corolla.
The condition of certain species of plants, in which the stamens and pistil do not mature simultaneously, so that these plants can never fertilize themselves.
To cut into two parts; to part into two divisions; to divide into pairs; to bisect.
Regularly dividing by pairs from bottom to top; as, a dichotomous stem.
A cutting in two; a division.
The property of presenting different colors by transmitted light, when viewed in two different directions, the colors being unlike in the direction of unlike or unequal axes.
Iolite; -- so called from its presenting two different colors when viewed in two different directions. See Iolite.
A salt of chromic acid containing two equivalents of the acid radical to one of the base; -- called also bichromate.
Having or exhibiting two colors.
Furnishing or giving two colors; -- said of defective vision, in which all the compound colors are resolvable into two elements instead of three.
An instrument for examining the dichroism of crystals.
Pertaining to the dichroscope, or to observations with it.
An ornamenting in squares or cubes.
The number or quantity of ten, particularly ten hides or skins; a dakir; as, a dicker of gloves.
A seat behind a carriage, for a servant.
Having the stamens and pistils in separate flowers.
A plant whose seeds divide into two seed lobes, or cotyledons, in germinating.
Having two cotyledons or seed lobes; as, a dicotyledonous plant.
Of or pertaining to dicrotism; as, a dicrotic pulse.
A condition in which there are two beats or waves of the arterial pulse to each beat of the heart.
A dictation or dictate.
To tell or utter so that another may write down; to inspire; to compose; as, to dictate a letter to an amanuensis.
To speak as a superior; to command; to impose conditions (on).
The act of dictating; the act or practice of prescribing; also that which is dictated.
One who dictates; one who prescribes rules and maxims authoritatively for the direction of others.
Pertaining or suited to a dictator; absolute.
The office, or the term of office, of a dictator; hence, absolute power.
Office of a dictator; dictatorship.
A book containing the words of a language, arranged alphabetically, with explanations of their meanings; a lexicon; a vocabulary; a wordbook.
An authoritative statement; a dogmatic saying; an apothegm.
A compound of a binary type containing two cyanogen groups or radicals; -- called also bicyanide.
An order of worms parasitic in cephalopods. They are remarkable for the extreme simplicity of their structure. The embryo exists in two forms.
Like or belonging to the Dicyemata.
Fitted or intended to teach; conveying instruction; preceptive; instructive; teaching some moral lesson; as, didactic essays.
The didactic method or system.
An animal having only two digits.
Having only two digits; two-toed.
A kind of triangular spade.
Of or relating to the Didelphia.
Having the uterus double; of or pertaining to the Didelphia.

Formerly, any marsupial; but the term is now restricted to an American genus which includes the opossums, of which there are many species. See Opossum. [Written also Didelphis.] See Illustration in Appendix.
A shrewd trick; an antic; a caper.
, the 2d pers. sing. imp. of Do.
Diduction; separation into distinct parts.

A rare metallic substance usually associated with the metal cerium; -- hence its name. It was formerly supposed to be an element, but has since been found to consist of two simpler elementary substances, neodymium and praseodymium. See Neodymium, and Praseodymium.
Growing in pairs or twins.
A Linn\'91an class of plants having four stamens disposed in pairs of unequal length.
Of or pertaining to the Didynamia; containing four stamens disposed in pairs of unequal length.

To pass from an animate to a lifeless state; to cease to live; to suffer a total and irreparable loss of action of the vital functions; to become dead; to expire; to perish; -- said of animals and vegetables; often with of, by, with, from, and rarely for, before the cause or occasion of death; as, to die of disease or hardships; to die by fire or the sword; to die with horror at the thought.
A small cube, marked on its faces with spots from one to six, and used in playing games by being shaken in a box and thrown from it. See Dice.
The same as Dihedral.
A narrative or history; a recital or relation.

Any substance or medium that transmits the electric force by a process different from conduction, as in the phenomena of induction; a nonconductor. separating a body electrified by induction, from the electrifying body.
The interbrain or thalamencephalon; -- sometimes abbreviated to dien. See Thalamencephalon.
An engraver of dies for stamping coins, medals, etc.
The process of engraving dies.
A small interval, less than any in actual practice, but used in the mathematical calculation of intervals.
A day on which courts are not held, as Sunday or any legal holiday.
A stock to hold the dies used for cutting screws.
Course of living or nourishment; what is eaten and drunk habitually; food; victuals; fare.
To cause to take food; to feed.
To eat; to take one's meals.
One who lives in accordance with prescribed rules for diet; a dieter.
Pertaining to diet, or to the rules of diet.
A rule of diet; a fixed allowance of food, as in workhouse, prison, etc.
One who diets; one who prescribes, or who partakes of, food, according to hygienic rules.
Of or performance to diet, or to the rules for regulating the kind and quantity of food to be eaten.
In a dietetical manner.
That part of the medical or hygienic art which relates to diet or food; rules for diet.
One skilled in dietetics.
Evil name; bad reputation; defamation.
To be or stand apart; to disagree; to be unlike; to be distinguished; -- with from.

The act of differing; the state or measure of being different or unlike; distinction; dissimilarity; unlikeness; variation; as, a difference of quality in paper; a difference in degrees of heat, or of light; what is the difference between the innocent and the guilty?
Distinct; separate; not the same; other.
Relating to or indicating a difference; creating a difference; discriminating; special; as, differential characteristics; differential duties; a differential rate.
An increment, usually an indefinitely small one, which is given to a variable quantity.
To distinguish or mark by a specific difference; to effect a difference in, as regards classification; to develop differential characteristics in; to specialize; to desynonymize.
The act of differentiating.
In a different manner; variously.
In a differing or different manner.
Hard to do or to make; beset with difficulty; attended with labor, trouble, or pains; not easy; arduous.
The state of being difficult, or hard to do; hardness; arduousness; -- opposed to easiness or facility; as, the difficulty of a task or enterprise; a work of difficulty.
The state of being diffident; distrust; want of confidence; doubt of the power, ability, or disposition of others.
Wanting confidence in others; distrustful.
Flowing apart or off; dissolving; not fixed.

The deflection and decomposition of light in passing by the edges of opaque bodies or through narrow slits, causing the appearance of parallel bands or fringes of prismatic colors, as by the action of a grating of fine lines or bars.
Material which, in the process of catalysis, has diffused or passed through the separating membrane.
To pour out and cause to spread, as a fluid; to cause to flow on all sides; to send out, or extend, in all directions; to spread; to circulate; to disseminate; to scatter; as to diffuse information.
Poured out; widely spread; not restrained; copious; full; esp., of style, opposed to concise or terse; verbose; prolix; as, a diffuse style; a diffuse writer.
The quality of being diffuse; especially, in writing, the use of a great or excessive number of word to express the meaning; copiousness; verbosity; prolixity.
The quality of being diffusible; capability of being poured or spread out.
Capable of flowing or spreading in all directions; that may be diffused.
The act of diffusing, or the state of being diffused; a spreading; extension; dissemination; circulation; dispersion.
The quality or state of being diffusive or diffuse; extensiveness; expansion; dispersion. Especially of style: Diffuseness; want of conciseness; prolixity.
To turn up, or delve in, (earth) with a spade or a hoe; to open, loosen, or break up (the soil) with a spade, or other sharp instrument; to pierce, open, or loosen, as if with a spade.
To work with a spade or other like implement; to do servile work; to delve.
A thrust; a punch; a poke; as, a dig in the side or the ribs. See Dig, v. t., 4.
Act, or state, of being twice married; deuterogamy.
Having two bellies; biventral; -- applied to muscles which are fleshy at each end and have a tendon in the middle, and esp. to the muscle which pulls down the lower jaw.
A division of Trematoda in which alternate generations occur, the immediate young not resembling their parents.
The faculty of multiplying in two ways; -- by ova fecundated by spermatic fluid, and asexually, as by buds. See Parthenogenesis.
To distribute or arrange methodically; to work over and classify; to reduce to portions for ready use or application; as, to digest the laws, etc.
To undergo digestion; as, food digests well or ill.
Capable of being digested.
The quality of being digestible; digestibility.
The act or process of digesting; reduction to order; classification; thoughtful consideration.
That which aids digestion, as a food or medicine.
One who, or that which, digs.
The act or the place of excavating.
To prepare; to put in order; hence, to dress, or put on; to array; to adorn.
One of the terminal divisions of a limb appendage; a finger or toe.
Of or performance to the fingers, or to digits; done with the fingers; as, digital compression; digital examination.
Any one of several extracts of foxglove (Digitalis), as the "French extract," the "German extract," etc., which differ among themselves in composition and properties.
A genus of plants including the foxglove.
A division into fingers or fingerlike processes; also, a fingerlike process.
Formed like a finger or fingers; finger-shaped; as, a digitiform root.
Walking on the toes; -- distinguished from plantigrade.
An animal that walks on its toes, as the cat, lion, wolf, etc.; -- distinguished from a plantigrade, which walks on the palm of the foot.
Parted like the fingers.
To finger; as, to digitize a pen.
A little finger or toe, or something resembling one.
To fight like gladiators; to contend fiercely; to dispute violently.
The act of thinking worthy; honor.
Marked with dignity; stately; as, a dignified judge.
To invest with dignity or honor; to make illustrious; to give distinction to; to exalt in rank; to honor.
The state of being worthy or honorable; elevation of mind or character; true worth; excellence.
Two signs or characters combined to express a single articulated sound; as ea in head, or th in bath.
Of or pertaining to a digraph.
To step or turn aside; to deviate; to swerve; especially, to turn aside from the main subject of attention, or course of argument, in writing or speaking.
The act of digressing or deviating, esp. from the main subject of a discourse; hence, a part of a discourse deviating from its main design or subject.
A bank; a dike.
Of or pertaining to the Digynia; having two styles.
Having two plane faces; as, the dihedral summit of a crystal.
A double iambus; a foot consisting of two iambuses (<?/ <?/ <?/ <?/).
A compound of a binary type containing two atoms of iodine; -- called also biniodide.
A red crystalline nitrogenous substance or artificial production, which by reduction passes directly to indigo.
A ditch; a channel for water made by digging.
To surround or protect with a dike or dry bank; to secure with a bank.
To bring into a condition of decay or partial ruin, by misuse or through neglect; to destroy the fairness and good condition of; -- said of a building.
The act of dilapidating, or the state of being dilapidated, reduced to decay, partially ruined, or squandered.
To expand; to distend; to enlarge or extend in all directions; to swell; -- opposed to contract; as, the air dilates the lungs; air is dilated by increase of heat.
To grow wide; to expand; to swell or extend in all directions.
One who, or that which, widens or expands.
The quality of being dilatory; lateness; slowness; tardiness; sluggishness.
Inclined to defer or put off what ought to be done at once; given the procrastination; delaying; procrastinating; loitering; as, a dilatory servant.
An argument which presents an antagonist with two or more alternatives, but is equally conclusive against him, whichever alternative he chooses.
The state or quality of being a dilettante; the desultory pursuit of art, science, or literature.
The quality of being diligent; carefulness; careful attention; -- the opposite of negligence.
Diligence; care; persevering endeavor.
Prosecuted with careful attention and effort; careful; painstaking; not careless or negligent.
A darling; a favorite.
A kind of stagecoach.
Ambiguous; of double meaning.
To make thinner or more liquid by admixture with something; to thin and dissolve by mixing.
The quality or state of being dilute.
The act of diluting, or the state of being diluted.
Of or pertaining to a flood or deluge, esp. to the great deluge in the days of Noah; diluvian.
Not bright or distinct; wanting luminousness or clearness; obscure in luster or sound; dusky; darkish; obscure; indistinct; overcast; tarnished.
To render dim, obscure, or dark; to make less bright or distinct; to take away the luster of; to darken; to dull; to obscure; to eclipse.

Measure in a single line, as length, breadth, height, thickness, or circumference; extension; measurement; -- usually, in the plural, measure in length and breadth, or in length, breadth, and thickness; extent; size; as, the dimensions of a room, or of a ship; the dimensions of a farm, of a kingdom.
Without dimensions; having no appreciable or noteworthy extent.
One of the Dimera.
Composed of, or having, two parts of each kind.
Ethane; -- sometimes so called because regarded as consisting of two methyl radicals. See Ethane.
Divided into two equal parts; reduced to half in shape or form.
To divide into two equal parts.
To make smaller in any manner; to reduce in bulk or amount; to lessen; -- opposed to augment or increase.
Capable of being diminished or lessened.
One who, or that which, diminishes anything.
The act of diminishing, or of making or becoming less; state of being diminished; reduction in size, quantity, or degree; -- opposed to augmentation or increase.
Below the average size; very small; little.
Something of very small size or value; an insignificant thing.
The quality of being diminutive; smallness; littleness; minuteness.
Leave to depart; a dismissing.
A cotton fabric employed for hangings and furniture coverings, and formerly used for women's under-garments. It is of many patterns, both plain and twilled, and occasionally is printed in colors.
In a dim or obscure manner; not brightly or clearly; with imperfect sight.
Somewhat dim; as, dimmish eyes.
The state or quality <?/ being dim; lack of brightness, clearness, or distinctness; dullness; obscurity.
Having the property of dimorphism; dimorphous.

Difference of form between members of the same species, as when a plant has two kinds of flowers, both hermaphrodite (as in the partridge berry), or when there are two forms of one or both sexes of the same species of butterfly.
Characterized by dimorphism; occurring under two distinct forms, not dependent on sex; dimorphic.
A slight natural depression or indentation on the surface of some part of the body, esp. on the cheek or chin.
An order of lamellibranchiate mollusks having an anterior and posterior adductor muscle, as the common clam. See Bivalve.
Like or pertaining to the Dimya.
Loud, confused, harsh noise; a loud, continuous, rattling or clanging sound; clamor; roar.
To strike with confused or clanging sound; to stun with loud and continued noise; to harass with clamor; as, to din the ears with cries.
A petty money of accounts of Persia.
To eat the principal regular meal of the day; to take dinner.
To give a dinner to; to furnish with the chief meal; to feed; as, to dine a hundred men.
One who often takes his dinner away from home, or in company.
To dash; to throw violently.
To strike; to thump; to pound.
The sound of, or as of, repeated strokes on a metallic body, as a bell; a repeated and monotonous sound.
A kind of boat used in the East Indies.
Quality of being dingy; a dusky hue.
A narrow dale; a small dell; a small, secluded, and embowered valley.
In a dangling manner.
A wild dog found in Australia, but supposed to have introduced at a very early period. It has a wolflike face, bushy tail, and a reddish brown color.
To deck; -- often with out or up.
A wether sheep between one and two years old.
The principal meal of the day, eaten by most people about midday, but by many (especially in cities) at a later hour.
One of the Dinosauria.

An order of extinct mesozoic reptiles, mostly of large size (whence the name). Notwithstanding their size, they present birdlike characters in the skeleton, esp. in the pelvis and hind limbs. Some walked on their three-toed hind feet, thus producing the large "bird tracks," so-called, of mesozoic sandstones; others were five-toed and quadrupedal. See Illust. of Compsognathus, also Illustration of Dinosaur in Appendix.
A large extinct proboscidean mammal from the miocene beds of Europe and Asia. It is remarkable fora pair of tusks directed downward from the decurved apex of the lower jaw.
A blow; a stroke.
A bishop, viewed in relation to his diocese; as, the diocesan of New York.
One who belongs to a diocese.

A genus of spinose, plectognath fishes, having the teeth of each jaw united into a single beaklike plate. They are able to inflate the body by taking in air or water, and, hence, are called globefishes, swellfishes, etc. fishes, and sea hedgehogs.
A Linn\'91an class of plants having the stamens and pistils on different plants.
In a di\'d2cious manner.
The condition of being di\'d2cious.
A Greek Cynic philosopher (412?-323 B. C.) who lived much in Athens and was distinguished for contempt of the common aims and conditions of life, and for sharp, caustic sayings.
A genus of large sea birds, including the albatross. See Albatross.
An insectivorous plant. See Venus's flytrap.
Relating to Dionysius, a monk of the 6th century; as, the Dionysian, or Christian, era.
A hydrous silicate of copper, occurring in emerald-green crystals.
An optical instrument, invented by Hipparchus, for taking altitudes, leveling, etc.
A unit employed by oculists in numbering glasses according to the metric system; a refractive power equal to that of a glass whose principal focal distance is one meter.
Of or pertaining to the dioptre, or to the metric system of numbering glasses.
Of or pertaining to dioptrics; assisting vision by means of the refraction of light; refractive; as, the dioptric system; a dioptric glass or telescope.

A mode of scenic representation, invented by Daguerre and Bouton, in which a painting is seen from a distance through a large opening. By a combination of transparent and opaque painting, and of transmitted and reflected light, and by contrivances such as screens and shutters, much diversity of scenic effect is produced.
Relating to the correcting or straightening out of something; corrective.
A genus of plants. See Yam.
A vase or drinking cup having two handles or ears.
An oxide containing two atoms of oxygen in each molecule; binoxide.
To plunge or immerse; especially, to put for a moment into a liquid; to insert into a fluid and withdraw again.
To immerse one's self; to become plunged in a liquid; to sink.
The action of dipping or plunging for a moment into a liquid.
Having two petals; two-petaled.
A white crystalline substance, C6H5.C6H5, obtained by leading benzene through a heated iron tube. It consists of two benzene or phenyl radicals united.
A very dangerous contagious disease in which the air passages, and especially the throat, become coated with a false membrane, produced by the solidification of an inflammatory exudation. Cf. Group.
Relating to diphtheria; diphtheritic.
Pertaining to, or connected with, diphtheria.
To form or pronounce as a diphthong; diphthongize.
Relating or belonging to a diphthong; having the nature of a diphthong.
To make into a diphthong; to pronounce as a diphthong.
Of the nature of diphthong; diphthongal.
Having two modes of embryonic development.
Having two leaves, as a calyx, etc.
Having two successive sets of teeth (deciduous and permanent), one succeeding the other; as, a diphyodont mammal; diphyodont dentition; -- opposed to monophyodont.
One of the free-swimming sexual zooids of Siphonophora.
Of or pertaining to two planes.

An instrument for determining the time of apparent noon. It consists of two mirrors and a plane glass disposed in the form of a prism, so that, by the reflections of the sun's rays from their surfaces, two images are presented to the eye, moving in opposite directions, and coinciding at the instant the sun's center is on the meridian.
Characterizing the ovum when it has two primary germinal layers.
Having the heart completely divided or double, one side systemic, the other pulmonary.
A form of micrococcus in which cocci are united in a binary manner. See Micrococcus.
The soft, spongy, or cancellated substance between the plates of the skull.
Partaking of the nature of two bodies; producing two substances.
A solid bounded by twenty-four similar quadrilateral faces. It is a hemihedral form of the hexoctahedron.
A letter or writing, usually under seal, conferring some privilege, honor, or power; a document bearing record of a degree conferred by a literary society or educational institution.
The art and practice of conducting negotiations between nations (particularly in securing treaties), including the methods and forms usually employed.
To invest with a title o<?/ privilege by diploma.
Pertaining to diplomacy; relating to the foreign ministers at a court, who are called the diplomatic body.
According to the rules of diplomacy; in the manner of a diplomatist; artfully.
The science of diplomas, or the art of deciphering ancient writings, and determining their age, authenticity, etc.; paleography.
A person employed in, or skilled in, diplomacy; a diplomat.
An order of myriapods having two pairs of legs on each segment; the Chilognatha.
Having twice as many stamens as petals, as the geranium.
A group of spiders having only two lunglike organs.

A group of ganoid fishes, including the living genera Ceratodus and Lepidosiren, which present the closest approximation to the Amphibia. The air bladder acts as a lung, and the nostrils open inside the mouth. See Ceratodus, and Illustration in Appendix.
Two metrical feet taken together, or included in one measure.
See Bone oil, under Bone.
One who, or that which, dips; especially, a vessel used to dip water or other liquid; a ladle.
The act or process of immersing.
A pungent, mobile, volatile liquid, C6H6, produced artificially from certain allyl derivatives. Though isomeric with benzine, it is very different in its chemical relations. Called also dipropinyl.
One of the hexane paraffins, found in petroleum, consisting of two propyl radicals. See Hexane.
An extinct Quaternary marsupial from Australia, about as large as the hippopotamus; -- so named because of its two large front teeth. See Illustration in Appendix.
A serpent whose bite was fabled to produce intense thirst.
One who has an irrepressible desire for alcoholic drinks.
Of or pertaining to dipsomania.
Excessive thirst produced by disease.

An extensive order of insects having only two functional wings and two balancers, as the house fly, mosquito, etc. They have a suctorial proboscis, often including two pairs of sharp organs (mandibles and maxill\'91) with which they pierce the skin of animals. They undergo a complete metamorphosis, their larv\'91 (called maggots) being usually without feet.
Having two wings only; belonging to the order Diptera.
A genus of trees found in the East Indies, some species of which produce a fragrant resin, other species wood oil. The fruit has two long wings.
Having two wings, as certain insects; belonging to the order Diptera.
A noun which has only two cases.
Anything consisting of two leaves
Containing two stones or nutlets.
A polymeric form of pyridine, C10H10N2, obtained as a colorless oil by the action of sodium on pyridine.
A crystalline nitrogenous base, C10H8N2, obtained by the reduction of pyridine.
The emission and diffusion of rays of light.
Ill-boding; portentous; as, dire omens.
Straight; not crooked, oblique, or circuitous; leading by the short or shortest way to a point or end; as, a direct line; direct means.
To arrange in a direct or straight line, as against a mark, or towards a goal; to point; to aim; as, to direct an arrow or a piece of ordnance.
The act of directing, of aiming, regulating, guiding, or ordering; guidance; management; superintendence; administration; as, the direction o.
Having power to direct; tending to direct, guide, or govern; showing the way.
In a direct manner; in a straight line or course.
One who, or that which, directs; one who regulates, guides, or orders; a manager or superintendent.
Having the quality of a director, or authoritative guide; directive.
Containing directions; enjoining; instructing; directorial.
A collection or body of directions, rules, or ordinances; esp., a book of directions for the conduct of worship; as, the Directory used by the nonconformists instead of the Prayer Book.
In a dire manner.
Any foul of filthy substance, as excrement, mud, dust, etc.; whatever, adhering to anything, renders it foul or unclean; earth; as, a wagonload of dirt.
The state of being dirty; filthiness; foulness; nastiness; baseness; sordidness.
Defiled with dirt; foul; nasty; filthy; not clean or pure; serving to defile; as, dirty hands; dirty water; a dirty white.
To foul; to make filthy; to soil; as, to dirty the clothes or hands.

A prefix from the Latin, whence F. d\'82s, or sometimes d\'82-, dis-. The Latin dis- appears as di- before b, d, g, l, m, n, r, v, becomes dif- before f, and either dis- or di- before j. It is from the same root as bis twice, and duo, E. two. See Two, and cf. Bi-, Di-, Dia-. Dis- denotes separation, a parting from, as in distribute, disconnect; hence it often has the force of a privative and negative, as in disarm, disoblige, disagree. Also intensive, as in dissever.
State of being disabled; deprivation or want of ability; absence of competent physical, intellectual, or moral power, means, fitness, and the like.

To render unable or incapable; to destroy the force, vigor, or power of action of; to deprive of competent physical or intellectual power; to incapacitate; to disqualify; to make incompetent or unfit for service; to impair.
To refuse to acknowledge; to deny; to disown.
To deprive of ornaments.
Deprivation of advantage; unfavorable or prejudicial quality, condition, circumstance, or the like; that which hinders success, or causes loss or injury.
To alienate or diminish the affection of; to make unfriendly or less friendly; to fill with discontent and unfriendliness.
State of being disaffected; alienation or want of affection or good will, esp. toward those in authority; unfriendliness; dislike.
To assert the contrary of; to contradict; to deny; -- said of that which has been asserted.
The act of disaffirming; denial; negation.
To reduce from the privileges of a forest to the state of common ground; to exempt from forest laws.
The separation of an aggregate body into its component parts.
To fail to accord; not to agree; to lack harmony; to differ; to be unlike; to be at variance.
Not agreeable, conformable, or congruous; <?/ontrary; unsuitable.
In a disagreeable manner; unsuitably; offensively.
The state of disagreeing; a being at variance; dissimilitude; diversity.
The act of disallowing; refusal to admit or permit; rejection.
To deprive of life.
To invalidate the consecration of; as, to disanoint a king.

To cease to appear or to be perceived; to pass from view, gradually or suddenly; to vanish; to be no longer seen; as, darkness disappears at the approach of light; a ship disappears as she sails from port.
Freed from a former connection or dependence; disconnected.

To defeat of expectation or hope; to hinder from the attainment of that which was excepted, hoped, or desired; to balk; as, a man is disappointed of his hopes or expectations, or his hopes, desires, intentions, expectations, or plans are disappointed; a bad season disappoints the farmer of his crops; a defeat disappoints an enemy of his spoil.
Defeated of expectation or hope; balked; as, a disappointed person or hope.
The act of disappointing, or the state of being disappointed; defeat or failure of expectation or hope; miscarriage of design or plan; frustration.
Severed from the appropriation or possession of a spiritual corporation.
To release from individual ownership or possession.
Disapprobation; dislike; censure; adverse judgment.
To pass unfavorable judgment upon; to condemn by an act of the judgment; to regard as wrong, unsuitable, or inexpedient; to censure; as, to disapprove the conduct of others.
In a disapproving manner.
To deprive of arms; to take away the weapons of; to deprive of the means of attack or defense; to render defenseless.
The act of divesting of armature.
To unsettle or disturb the order or due arrangement of; to throw out of order.
The act of disarranging, or the state of being disarranged; confusion; disorder.
To throw into disorder; to break the array of.
Want of array or regular order; disorder; confusion.
One who disarticulates and prepares skeletons.

The decomposition of complex substances, within the organism, into simpler ones suitable only for excretion, with evolution of energy, -- a normal nutritional process the reverse of assimilation; downward metabolism.
An unpropitious or baleful aspect of a planet or star; malevolent influence of a heavenly body; hence, an ill portent.
To blast by the influence of a baleful star.
Full of unpropitious stellar influences; unpropitious; ill-boding.
To deprive of credit or authority; to discredit.

To refuse strongly and solemnly to own or acknowledge; to deny responsibility for, approbation of, an the like; to disclaim; to disown; as, he was charged with embezzlement, but he disavows the crime.
To loose the bands of; to set free; to disunite; to scatter; to disperse; to break up the organization of; especially, to dismiss from military service; as, to disband an army.
To expel from the bar, or the legal profession; to deprive (an attorney, barrister, or counselor) of his status and privileges as such.
To debase or degrade.
To drive from a bench or seat.
Converting forest land into cleared or arable land; removal of a forest.
To rid of a burden; to free from a load borne or from something oppressive; to unload; to disencumber; to relieve.
The act of disbursing or paying out.
To disburden; to relieve of a load.
A flat round plate
To pull off shoes or sandals from.
Unshod; barefooted; -- in distinction from calced.
To deprive of capacity; to incapacitate.
To throw out of one's hand, as superfluous cards; to lay aside (a card or cards).
The act of discarding; also, the card or cards discarded.
To see and identify by noting a difference or differences; to note the distinctive character of; to discriminate; to distinguish.
To see or understand the difference; to make distinction; as, to discern between good and evil, truth and falsehood.
One who, or that which, discerns, distinguishes, perceives, or judges; as, a discerner of truth, of right and wrong.
In a manner to be discerned; perceptibly; visibly.
The act of discerning.
To tear in pieces; to rend.
The act of pulling to pieces, or of separating the parts.
To relieve of a charge, load, or burden; to empty of a load or cargo; to unburden; to unload; as, to discharge a vessel.
The act of discharging; the act of relieving of a charge or load; removal of a load or burden; unloading; as, the discharge of a ship; discharge of a cargo.
Bearing the stamens on a discoid outgrowth of the receptacle; -- said of a subclass of plants. Cf. Calycifloral.
A genus of Branchiopoda, having a disklike shell, attached by one valve, which is perforated by the peduncle.
To teach; to train.
Capable of being disciplined or improved by instruction and training.

One who disciplines; one who excels in training, especially with training, especially with regard to order and obedience; one who enforces rigid discipline; a stickler for the observance of rules and methods of training; as, he is a better disciplinarian than scholar.
The treatment suited to a disciple or learner; education; development of the faculties by instruction and exercise; training, whether physical, mental, or moral.
To educate; to develop by instruction and exercise; to train.
To renounce all claim to deny; ownership of, or responsibility for; to disown; to disavow; to reject.
One who disclaims, disowns, or renounces.
To take off a cloak from; to uncloak.
To unclose; to open; -- applied esp. to eggs in the sense of to hatch.
The act of disclosing, uncovering, or revealing; bringing to light; exposure.
A shutting off; exclusion.
A thrower of the discus
A division of amphibians having suctorial disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
Having sucking disks on the toes, as the tree frogs.
Having the form of a disk, as those univalve shells which have the whorls in one plane, so as to form a disk, as the pearly nautilus.

One of a species of coccoliths, having an oval discoidal body, with a thick strongly refracting rim, and a thinner central portion. One of them measures about <frac1x50000/ of an inch in its longest diameter.
To alter the natural hue or color of; to change to a different color; to stain; to tinge; as, a drop of wine will discolor water; silver is discolored by sea water.
The act of discoloring, or the state of being discolored; alteration of hue or appearance.
Altered in color; <?/tained.
To scatter in fight; to put to rout; to defeat.
To discourage; to deject.
Causing discomfort; occasioning uneasiness; making sad.
To mention with disapprobation; to blame; to disapprove.
To deprive of privileges.
To disarrange; to interfere with; to disturb; to disorder; to unsettle; to break up.
The state of being discomposed; disturbance; disorder; agitation; perturbation.
To break up the harmonious progress of; to throw into disorder or confusion; as, the emperor disconcerted the plans of his enemy.
To differ; to disagree; to dissent.
Destitute of consolation; deeply dejected and dispirited; hopelessly sad; comfortless; filled with grief; as, a bereaved and disconsolate parent.

The act of discontinuing, or the state of being discontinued; want of continued connection or continuity; breaking off; cessation; interruption; as, a discontinuance of conversation or intercourse; discontinuance of a highway or of travel.

A breaking off or interruption of an estate, which happened when an alienation was made by a tenant in tail, or other tenant, seized in right of another, of a larger estate than the tenant was entitled to, whereby the party ousted or injured was driven to his real action, and could not enter. This effect of such alienation is now obviated by statute in both England and the United States.
To be separated or severed; to part.
One who discontinues, or breaks off or away from; an absentee.
Not continuous; interrupted; broken off.
Exhibiting a dissolution of continuity; gaping.

Want of concord or agreement; absence of unity or harmony in sentiment or action; variance leading to contention and strife; disagreement; -- applied to persons or to things, and to thoughts, feelings, or purposes.
Disagreeing; incongruous; being at variance; clashing; opposing; not harmonious.
Deprived of the privileges or form of a body corporate.
To deduct from an account, debt, charge, and the like; to make an abatement of; as, merchants sometimes discount five or six per cent for prompt payment of bills.
A counting off or deduction made from a gross sum on any account whatever; an allowance upon an account, debt, demand, price asked, and the like; something taken or deducted.
To ruffle or discompose the countenance of; to put of countenance; to put to shame; to abash.

To extinguish the courage of; to dishearten; to depress the spirits of; to deprive of confidence; to deject; -- the opposite of encourage; as, he was discouraged in his undertaking; he need not be discouraged from a like attempt.
Capable of being discouraged; easily disheartened.
The act of discouraging, or the state of being discouraged; depression or weakening of confidence; dejection.

The power of the mind to reason or infer by running, as it were, from one fact or reason to another, and deriving a conclusion; an exercise or act of this power; reasoning; range of reasoning faculty.
To exercise reason; to employ the mind in judging and inferring; to reason.
To utter or give forth; to speak.
The writer of a treatise or dissertation.
Reasoning; characterized by reasoning; passing from premises to consequences; discursive.
Rudeness of behavior or language; ill manners; manifestation of disrespect; incivility.
To dissolve covenant with.
One who discovers; one who first comes to the knowledge of something; one who discovers an unknown country, or a new principle, truth, or fact.
A scout; an explorer.
Not covert; not within the bonds of matrimony; unmarried; -- applied either to a woman who has never married or to a widow.
An uncovered place or part.
The action of discovering; exposure to view; laying open; showing; as, the discovery of a plot.
The act of discrediting or disbelieving, or the state of being discredited or disbelieved; as, later accounts have brought the story into discredit.
To refuse credence to; not to accept as true; to disbelieve; as, the report is discredited.
Possessed of discernment, especially in avoiding error or evil, and in the adaptation of means to ends; prudent; sagacious; judicious; not rash or heedless; cautious.
At discretion; according to one's discretion or judgment.
Marking distinction or separation; disjunctive.
Capable of being discriminated.
The eliminant of the n partial differentials of any homogenous function of n variables. See Eliminant.
Having the difference marked; distinguished by certain tokens.
The state of being discriminated; distinctness.
Marking a difference; distinguishing.
The act of discriminating, distinguishing, or noting and marking differences.
Observing distinctions; making differences; discriminating.
The act of reclining at table according to the manner of the ancients at their meals.
Passing from one thing to another; ranging over a wide field; roving; digressive; desultory.
A quoit; a circular plate of some heavy material intended to be pitched or hurled as a trial of strength and skill
To break to pieces; to shatter.
The act or process of discussing by breaking up, or dispersing, as a tumor, or the like.
Able or tending to discuss or disperse tumors or coagulated matter.
Serving to disperse morbid matter; discussive; as, a discutient application.
A feeling of contempt and aversion; the regarding anything as unworthy of or beneath one; scorn.
To think unworthy; to deem unsuitable or unbecoming; as, to disdain to do a mean act.
An interval of two octaves, or a fifteenth; -- called also bisdiapason.
Lack of ease; uneasiness; trouble; vexation; disquiet.
To deprive of ease; to disquiet; to trouble; to distress.
Abounding with disease; producing diseases; as, a diseaseful climate.
To deprive of an elder or elders, or of the office of an elder.
To remove from on board a vessel; to put on shore; to land; to debark; as, the general disembarked the troops.
To free from embarrassment, or perplexity; to clear; to extricate.
To clear from a bay.
Divested of a body; ceased to be corporal; incorporeal.
To divest of the or corporeal existence.
To pour out or discharge at the mouth, as a stream; to vent; to discharge into an ocean, a lake, etc.
To take or let out the bowels or interior parts of; to eviscerate.
Deprived of, or removed from, a bower.
The act of disenchanting, or state of being disenchanted.
To free from encumbrance, or from anything which clogs, impedes, or obstructs; to disburden.

To release from that with which anything is engaged, engrossed, involved, or entangled; to extricate; to detach; to set free; to liberate; to clear; as, to disengage one from a party, from broils and controversies, from an oath, promise, or occupation; to disengage the affections a favorite pursuit, the mind from study.
The act of disengaging or setting free, or the state of being disengaged.

To free from entanglement; to release from a condition of being intricately and confusedly involved or interlaced; to reduce to orderly arrangement; to straighten out; as, to disentangle a skein of yarn.
To release from thralldom or slavery; to give freedom to; to disinthrall.
To dethrone; to depose from sovereign authority.
To disembowel; to let out or draw forth, as the entrails.
The condition of being disestablished.
To feel an absence of esteem for; to regard with disfavor or slight contempt; to slight.
To deprive of exercise; to leave untrained.
Want of favor of favorable regard; disesteem; disregard.
To withhold or withdraw favor from; to regard with disesteem; to show disapprobation of; to discountenance.
To exclude from fellowship; to refuse intercourse with, as an associate.
That which disfigures; a defacement; a blot.
To reduce the flesh or obesity of.
To clear or deprive of forests or trees.
To deprive of that with which anything is furnished (furniture, equipments, etc.); to strip; to render destitute; to divest.
To deprive of glory; to treat with indignity.
To eject or discharge by the throat and mouth; to vomit; to pour forth or throw out with violence, as if from the mouth; to discharge violently or in great quantities from a confined place.
The condition of being out of favor; loss of favor, regard, or respect.
To put out favor; to dismiss with dishonor.
Wanting grace; unpleasing; disagreeable.
The process of separation, or the condition of being separate, as of the molecules of a body.
To dissatisfy; to disaffect; to anger.
To change the guise or appearance of; especially, to conceal by an unusual dress, or one intended to mislead or deceive.
Artificial language or manner assumed for deception; false appearance; counterfeit semblance or show.
The state of being disguised.
One who wears a disguise; an actor in a masquerade; a masker.
To provoke disgust or strong distaste in; to cause (any one) loathing, as of the stomach; to excite aversion in; to offend the moral taste of; -- often with at, with, or by.
That causes disgust; sickening; offensive; revolting.
A vessel, as a platter, a plate, a bowl, used for serving up food at the table.
To put in a dish, ready for the table.
An undress; a loose, negligent dress; deshabille.
To discourage; to deprive of courage and hope; to depress the spirits of; to deject.
To suffer (the hair) to hang loosely or disorderly; to spread or throw (the hair) in disorder; -- used chiefly in the passive participle.
Having the hair in loose disorder.
Dishonorable; shameful; indecent; unchaste; lewd.

To deprive of honor; to disgrace; to bring reproach or shame on; to treat with indignity, or as unworthy in the sight of others; to stain the character of; to lessen the reputation of; as, the duelist dishonors himself to maintain his honor.
Wanting in honor; not honorable; bringing or deserving dishonor; staining the character, and lessening the reputation; shameful; disgraceful; base.
To deprive of humor or desire; to put out of humor.
A European bird; the wagtail.
To disenchant; to free from illusion.
To free from bitterness.
To free from the barriers or restrictions of a park.
To make worse; -- the opposite of improve.
Reduction from a better to a worse state; as, disimprovement of the earth.
To liberate from prison.
To deprive of corporate powers, rights, or privileges; to divest of the condition of a corporate body.
The act of disinfecting; purification from infecting matter.
One who, or that which, disinfects; an apparatus for applying disinfectants.
To divest of flame or ardor.
Not ingenuous; wanting in noble candor or frankness; not frank or open; uncandid; unworthily or meanly artful.

To cut off from an inheritance or from hereditary succession; to prevent, as an heir, from coming into possession of any property or right, which, by law or custom, would devolve on him in the course of descent.
To render insecure; to put in danger.
The process by which anything is disintegrated; the condition of anything which is disintegrated
To take out of the grave or tomb; to unbury; to exhume; to dig up.
Indifference to profit; want of regard to private advantage; disinterestedness.
The state or quality of being disinterested; impartiality.
To free from thralldom; to disenthrall.
A releasing from thralldom or slavery; disenthrallment.
Disjointed; unconnected; -- opposed to conjoint.

To separate the joints of; to separate, as parts united by joints; to put out of joint; to force out of its socket; to dislocate; as, to disjoint limbs; to disjoint bones; to disjoint a fowl in carving.
In a disjointed state.
The act of disjoining; disunion; separation; a parting; as, the disjunction of soul and body.
Tending to disjoin; separating; disjoining.
In a disjunctive manner; separately.
A discus; a quoit.
To regard with dislike or aversion; to disapprove; to disrelish.
To tear limb from limb; to dismember.
The act of displacing, or the state of being displaced.
To drive from a lodge or place of rest; to remove from a place of quiet or repose; as, shells resting in the sea at a considerate depth are not dislodged by storms.
The act or process of dislodging, or the state of being dislodged.
To put at a distance; to remove.
Want of loyalty; lack of fidelity; violation of allegiance.
To divest of coat of mail.
The quality of being dismal; gloominess.
To strip or deprive of dress; to divest.
To free from the bonds of marriage; to divorce.
The act of dismasting; the state of being dismasted.
To disable with alarm or apprehensions; to depress the spirits or courage of; to deprive or firmness and energy through fear; to daunt; to appall; to terrify.
Loss of courage and firmness through fear; overwhelming and disabling terror; a sinking of the spirits; consternation.
To tear limb from limb; to dilacerate; to disjoin member from member; to tear or cut in pieces; to break up.
To send away; to give leave of departure; to cause or permit to go; to put away.
The act dismissing or sending away; permission to leave; leave to depart; dismissal; as, the dismission of the grand jury.
To redeem from mortgage.
To come down; to descend.
To throw or remove from a horse; to unhorse; as, the soldier dismounted his adversary.
Neglecting or refusing to obey; omitting to do what is commanded, or doing what is prohibited; refractory; not observant of duty or rules prescribed by authority; -- applied to persons and acts.
The act of disobliging.
A disobliging act; an offense.
To do an act which contravenes the will or desires of; to offend by an act of unkindness or incivility; to displease; to refrain from obliging; to be unaccommodating to.
Not obliging; not disposed to do a favor; unaccommodating; as, a disobliging person or act.
Want or difference of belief; disbelief.
Want of order or regular disposition; lack of arrangement; confusion; disarray; as, the troops were thrown into disorder; the papers are in disorder.
To disturb the order of; to derange or disarrange; to throw into confusion; to confuse.
