One who, or that which, dusts; a utensil that frees from dust
Without dust; as a dustless path.
One whose employment is to remove dirt and defuse.
An old rural game.
Filled, covered, or sprinkled with dust; clouded with dust; as, a dusty table; also, reducing to dust.
The language spoken in Holland.
Fulfilling duty; dutiful; having the sentiments due to a superior, or to one to whom respect or service is owed; obedient; as, a duteous son or daughter.

Performing, or ready to perform, the duties required by one who has the right to claim submission, obedience, or deference; submissive to natural or legal superiors; obedient, as to parents or superiors; as, a dutiful son or daughter; a dutiful ward or servant; a dutiful subject.
That which is due; payment.
Of or belonging to the duumviri or the duumvirate.
The union of two men in the same office; or the office, dignity, or government of two men thus associated, as in ancient Rome.
The scholastic name for the theme or subject of a fugue, the answer being called the comes, or companion.
A small South African antelope (Cephalous mergens); -- called also impoon, and deloo.
A kind of slide valve. See Slide valve, under Slide.
A dwarf supposed to dwell in rocks and hills and to be skillful in working metals.
The deadly nightshade (Atropa Belladonna), having stupefying qualities.
A piece of wood set between two studs, posts, etc., to stiffen and support them.
To delay; to linger.
To diminish; to become less; to shrink; to waste or consume away; to become degenerate; to fall away.
To break; to disperse.
Two units treated as one; a couple; a pair.
Pertaining to the number two; of two parts or elements.
A name applied in Germany to the Permian formation, there consisting of two principal groups.
To stain; to color; to give a new and permanent color to, as by the application of dyestuffs.
Material used for dyeing; a dyestuff.
The process or art of fixing coloring matters permanently and uniformly in the fibers of wool, cotton, etc.
One whose occupation is to dye cloth and the like.
Any wood from which coloring matter is extracted for dyeing.
In the act of dying; destined to death; mortal; perishable; as, dying bodies.
Of or pertaining to dying or death; as, dying bed; dying day; dying words; also, simulating a dying state.
In a dying manner; as if at the point of death.
An instrument for measuring the intensity of the photogenic (light-producing) rays, and computing the power of object glasses.
A unit of measure for dynamical effect or work; a foot pound. See Foot pound.
Of or pertaining to dynamics; belonging to energy or power; characterized by energy or production of force.
The moving moral, as well as physical, forces of any kind, or the laws which relate to them.
One who accounts for material phenomena by a theory of dynamics.

An explosive substance consisting of nitroglycerin absorbed by some inert, porous solid, as infusorial earth, sawdust, etc. It is safer than nitroglycerin, being less liable to explosion from moderate shocks, or from spontaneous decomposition.
One who uses dynamite; esp., one who uses it for the destruction of life and property.
Destroying by dynamite, for political ends.
The act of setting free the dynamic powers of a medicine, as by shaking the bottle containing it.
Pertaining to the development of electricity, especially electrical currents, by power; producing electricity or electrical currents by mechanical power.
A dynamometer to which is attached a device for automatically registering muscular power.
An apparatus for measuring force or power; especially, muscular effort of men or animals, or the power developed by a motor, or that required to operate machinery.
The art or process of measuring forces doing work.
A ruler; a governor; a prince.
One of a group of gigantic, horned beetles, including Dynastus Neptunus, and the Hercules beetle (D. Hercules) of tropical America, which grow to be six inches in length.
An inseparable prefix, fr. the Greek ill, bad, hard, difficult, and the like; cf. the prefixes, Skr. dus-, Goth. tuz-, OHG. zur-, G. zer-, AS. to-, Icel. tor-, Ir. do-.
Impairment of any of the senses, esp. of touch.
An ill habit or state of the constitution; -- formerly regarded as dependent on a morbid condition of the blood and humors.
A mineral consisting of antimony and silver.
Unfavorable; not commendatory; -- opposed to eulogistic.
A resinous substance formed in the decomposition of cholic acid of bile; -- so called because it is difficult to solve.
Difficult and painful menstruation.
Bad legislation; the enactment of bad laws.

A kind of indigestion; a state of the stomach in which its functions are disturbed, without the presence of other diseases, or, if others are present, they are of minor importance. Its symptoms are loss of appetite, nausea, heartburn, acrid or fetid eructations, a sense of weight or fullness in the stomach, etc.
A person afflicted with dyspepsia.
An insoluble albuminous body formed from casein and other proteid substances by the action of gastric juice.
A difficulty in producing vocal sounds; enfeebled or depraved voice.
Impatience under affliction; morbid restlessness; dissatisfaction; the fidgets.
Affected with shortness of breath; relating to dyspn<?/a.
The doctrine of purposelessness; a term applied by Haeckel to that branch of physiology which treats of rudimentary organs, in view of their being useless to the life of the organism.
Pertaining to, or afflicted with, dysury.
The Chinese yellow antelope (Procapra gutturosa), a remarkably swift-footed animal, inhabiting the deserts of Central Asia, Thibet, and China.
The kiang, a wild horse or wild ass of Thibet (Asinus hemionus).
